awd_titl_txt: RAPID: Monitoring subsurface water storage dynamics associated with the 2023 extreme snowfall events in precipitation-limited systems
awd_abstract_narration:
Many areas in mountainous regions are experiencing more frequent and extreme weather conditions, such as heavy snowfall and drought, due to global warming. The impacts of these changing weather patterns on water resources available to society and ecosystems are still not fully understood. In spring 2023, many cooler regions in the western US received extremely heavy snowfalls, and in some locations, the recorded snow water equivalent exceeded historical values. This research aims to determine how mountain hydrological systems respond to such exceptionally heavy snowfall. This research will focus on determining how much of the melted snow water seeps into the ground during the wet season and how plants utilize the water stored in the soil and rocks during the dry summer. The scientific data collected through this study will provide valuable insights into how groundwater mitigates the adverse effects of climate change. Additionally, this project will offer training opportunities for one graduate student and produce educational materials for a course offered to hydrology graduate students from approximately ten universities. The valuable data collected for this project has potential to improve computational simulation techniques, which could inform future water resource management and benefit society.

This research will use advanced geophysical imaging techniques to understand how anomalously wet conditions impact how meltwater enters and travels through the subsurface, and how subsurface water becomes available for use by vegetation, streamflow, and groundwater recharge. The study will be carried out at two sites in the Dry Creek Experimental Watershed near Boise, Idaho, where existing hydrometeorological information will supplement new geophysical imaging methods. Time-lapse electrical resistivity tomography will be used to monitor the daily or weekly resistivity variations related to subsurface water storage changes. A newly developed resistivity inversion scheme incorporating critical zone subsurface structure will be used to reconstruct the spatiotemporal resistivity distribution along a transect at each study site. The site-specific petrophysical relationship between resistivity and water content will also be determined such that the subsurface water dynamics can be estimated from resistivity data. The study will complement ongoing efforts investigating water uptake strategies by plants, streamflow generation, and groundwater recharge to enhance understanding of how extreme weather events impact hydrological processes in mountain systems. 

This award is co-funded by the Hydrologic Sciences and Geophysics programs.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

Intellectual Merit

Mountainous headwater catchments play an important role in providing fresh water to our river and groundwater system. It is imperative to have a mechanistic understanding of the dynamic processes occurring in these catchments, particularly under climate change and intensified human activities. In the spring of 2023, a historically high snowfall occurred in many parts of the western US, including Boise Batholith in Idaho and Wasatch Mountain in Utah. This project used geophysical methods to collect data that reflected the subsurface water storage changes at two sites in the Dry Creek Experimental Watershed in Idaho. The electrical resistivity of the subsurface was monitored biweekly at one site and daily at the other site from July 2023 to November 2023. Seismic refraction tests were also performed at the two sites to determine the critical zone subsurface structure. Other monitored data include weather conditions, shallow soil moisture, and plant evapotranspiration. Preliminary analysis of one site found that the moisture dynamics in the shallow soil layer and the deep weathered bedrock layer were asynchronous, implying different recharge/discharge mechanisms for different parts of the subsurface. Hydrologic modeling incorporating subsurface critical zone structure was also developed under this project for one site, and the results indicated that the subsurface structure could affect the partitioning of precipitation in the catchment. In summary, this project generated valuable subsurface water storage data and hydrologic models that provided new insights into the partitioning of precipitation in semi-arid mountainous catchments. 


Broader Impact

This project provided research training and professional development opportunities for two graduate students, who regularly visited the field sites and participated in most of the geophysical tests. One of the graduate students processed some of the geophysical data and performed formal analyses. One undergraduate student and two other graduate students attended at least two field geophysical tests and gained valuable field experiences that were not part of their curriculum or thesis research. This project supported one of the graduate students and the PI in presenting some of the results and preliminary findings at two professional conferences. The datasets generated by this project will be important educational material for students/researchers to learn and practice their data processing skills. The results and new findings will also inspire hydrologists to develop new hypotheses for subsurface water dynamics in semi-arid catchments.
